awd_titl_txt: Transition, turbulence, and transport in MHD duct flow
awd_abstract_narration:
0966527
Zikanov

The project is a part of the cooperation research activities conducted by the University of Michigan Dearborn, MI, USA and the Ilmenau University of Technology, Germany. It addresses the fundamental questions of interaction between flows of electrically conducting fluids and magnetic fields. 

Intellectual Merit:

The project advances our understanding of flows of electrically conducting fluids affected by magnetic fields. The main attention will be given to typical technological and laboratory flows of liquid metals and oxide melts. Model flows in a rectangular duct will be used to investigate how the magnetic field affects the transition to turbulence and properties of turbulent flows, in particular, their ability to transport heat and admixtures. On the basis of the acquired understanding, the PI will search for optimal control methods of electromagnetic flow. 

Broader Impact:

The results of the research are expected to advance the understanding, modeling, and optimization of the processing of electromagnetic materials, such as steel, aluminum, and semi-conductor crystals, as well as for the design of lithium cooling blankets for future nuclear fusion reactors. In all such technological processes, optimization of the field flow interaction is a key to reduction of energy consumption and environmental impact. 

The project will foster a competitive research environment and dynamic innovative instruction at the University of Michigan Dearborn, an institution focused on serving the metropolitan Detroit community. A graduate and several undergraduate students will be trained in the fields of turbulence theory, magnetohydrodynamics, and computational modeling. Close international cooperation strengthens the research and will establish new ties between the U.S. and German science communities. It also opens opportunities for students at the University of Michigan Dearborn to enrich their education via participation in international collaboration activities, visits to foreign research centers, and interaction with visiting German scientists.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In the project, we analyze how a strong magnetic field affects flows of electrically conducting fluids, such as liquid metals. The stuation is usually found in advanced technologies of steel and aluminum production and in growth of semiconductor crystals, where magnetic fields help to produce cleaner and more homogeneous materials at reduced cost, energy consumption, and environmental impact by suppressing unwanted flows in the melts. The results of the project concern transitional (between fully laminar and fully turbulent) states, in which such flows are often found. We discover that the flow structure in such states is complex and dominated by previously unknown features, such as concentration of remaining turbulence near walls parallel to the magnetic field and localized turbulent spots. Our results explain a longstanding controversy of contradicting experimental data. Finally, we analyze how the flow's transformation under the influence of a magnetic field changes its ability to transport heat and admixtures.

The project has been conducted as a collaboration work between the US and German scientists. It has helped to established close collaboration ties that continue to other areas of research. Several graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Michigan - Dearborn have participated in research and received extensive training in advanced areas of engineering, physics, and computational mathematics. 


Last Modified: 07/31/2014
Modified by: Oleg Zikanov

Images (1 of )
  • Turbulent vortices in a flow within a duct with strong imposed magnetic field. The vortices are located near the walls parallel to the magnetic field, while the rest of the flow is laminar.
    D. Krasnov, T. Boeck, O. Zikanov
    Public Domain
    Oleg Zikanov
    Turbulence in a duct flow with strong magnetic field
  • Localized turbulent spots in a flow in a duct with imposed magnetic field
    D. Krasnov, T. Boeck, O. Zikanov
    Public Domain
    Oleg Zikanov
    Localized turbulent spots
